deities.description: The Enlightened One, Teacher of Liberation

deities.title: üßò Gautama Buddha
deities.description: The Awakened One, Teacher of the Dharma

heroes.title: üôè Dalai Lama
heroes.description: The spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, believed to be the reincarnation of Avalokiteshvara, the Bodhisattva of Compassion. The current (14th) Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, is a Nobel Peace Prize laure

heroes.title: üëë King Songtsen Gampo
heroes.description: Tibetan king (7th century CE) who introduced Buddhism to Tibet. Considered an emanation of Avalokiteshvara. Built the first Buddhist temples in Tibet including the Jokhang.

heroes.title: üêâ Nagarjuna
heroes.description: The Second Buddha, Founder of Madhyamaka Philosophy

heroes.title: üßò Shantideva
heroes.description: 8th century Indian Buddhist monk and scholar, author of the Bodhicharyavatara (Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life), one of the most important texts on compassion and the bodhisattva path.

heroes.title: üìø Tsongkhapa
heroes.description: Great Tibetan Buddhist teacher (1357-1419) and founder of the Gelug school of Tibetan Buddhism. Considered an emanation of Manjushri, the Bodhisattva of Wisdom.

creatures.title: üêç Nagas
creatures.description: Serpent Deities, Guardians of Waters and Wisdom

concepts.title: üôè Bodhisattva
concepts.description: An enlightened being who delays entry into final nirvana in order to help all sentient beings achieve liberation. The bodhisattva ideal is central to Mahayana Buddhism. Major bodhisattvas include Aval

concepts.title: üíó Compassion (Karuna)
concepts.description: One of the central virtues in Buddhism, the wish for all beings to be free from suffering. Combined with wisdom, compassion is the foundation of the bodhisattva path and is personified by Avalokiteshv

cosmology.title: üíÄ Buddhist Afterlife - Bardo, Rebirth & Nirvana
cosmology.description:
In Buddhism, death is not an ending but a transition. The consciousness exits the dying body and
                enters the bardo‚Äîan intermediate state between lives‚Äîwhere it experiences visions based

cosmology.title: üåÄ Buddhist Creation - Interdependent Origination
cosmology.description:
Buddhism uniquely teaches that there is no creation by a supreme deity. Instead, all phenomena arise
                dependently through an endless chain of causes and conditions. Nothing possesses in

cosmology.title: üîó Dependent Origination
cosmology.description: The fundamental Buddhist doctrine that all phenomena arise in dependence upon multiple causes and conditions. Nothing exists independently or permanently. The twelve links explain how suffering and re

cosmology.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Karma
cosmology.description: The principle that all intentional actions have consequences that determine future conditions. In Buddhism, karma drives the cycle of rebirth (samsara) and can only be transcended through enlightenmen

cosmology.title: üî• Klesha
cosmology.description: The three poisons or mental afflictions: greed (raga), hatred (dvesha), and delusion (moha). These are the root causes of suffering and bind beings to samsara.

cosmology.title: ‚ú® Nirvana
cosmology.description: The ultimate goal of Buddhist practice, the state of liberation from suffering, desire, and the cycle of rebirth. Literally means "extinguishing" - the extinction of greed, hatred, and delusion.

cosmology.title: üè∞ Potala Palace
cosmology.description: The sacred abode of Avalokiteshvara and historic residence of the Dalai Lama in Lhasa, Tibet. Named after Mount Potalaka, the mythical abode of Avalokiteshvara.

cosmology.title: The Six Realms of Existence
cosmology.description: The six realms of existence (Sanskrit: gati or bhava) are the destinations for rebirth in Buddhist cosmology, depicted in the Bhavachakra (Wheel of Becoming). These realms are driven by karma‚Äîthe cons

herbs.title: üå≥ Bodhi Tree
herbs.description: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha. The original tree in Bodh Gaya is one of Buddhism's most sacred sites.

herbs.title: ü™∑ Lotus
herbs.description: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening. It grows from mud yet remains unstained, representing the potential for enlightenment within samsara. Different colored lotu

herbs.title: üçµ Herbal Preparations
herbs.description: Traditional methods of preparing sacred herbs, incense, and medicines used in Buddhist rituals, meditation, and healing practices.

herbs.title: üåø Sandalwood
herbs.description: Sacred fragrant wood used in incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming scent aids concentration and is believed to purify the mind and environment.

rituals.title: üìÖ Buddhist Calendar
rituals.description: The Buddhist calendar includes major festivals like Vesak (Buddha's birth, enlightenment, and death), Uposatha days (observance days), and various regional celebrations.

rituals.title: üïØÔ∏è Offerings
rituals.description: Traditional offerings include water, flowers, incense, light (candles/lamps), and food. These represent purification, impermanence, devotion, wisdom, and generosity.

creatures.name: Garuda
creatures.description: Divine eagle-man, king of birds and mount of Vishnu, sworn enemy of serpents

creatures.name: Makara
creatures.description: Aquatic creature with crocodile/elephant features, vahana of Varuna and Ganga, symbol of water and fertility

creatures.name: Nagas
creatures.description: Serpent beings with human and snake features, guardians of treasures and waters, rulers of the underworld

concepts.name: Bodhisattva
concepts.description: Enlightened being who vows to delay nirvana to liberate all sentient beings

concepts.name: Pratƒ´tyasamutpƒÅda
concepts.description: Fundamental doctrine that all phenomena arise through interconnected causes and conditions

concepts.name: Dharma
concepts.description: Cosmic law, righteousness, duty, and moral order that sustains the universe

concepts.name: Karma
concepts.description: Law of cause and effect governing action and consequence across lifetimes

concepts.name: Karuna
concepts.description: Universal compassion, the wish for all beings to be free from suffering

concepts.name: Klesha
concepts.description: Mental afflictions: greed, hatred, and delusion that bind beings to samsara

concepts.name: Maya
concepts.description: Cosmic illusion that veils the true nature of reality and creates the appearance of multiplicity

concepts.name: Nirvana
concepts.description: Liberation from suffering and the cycle of rebirth, extinction of greed, hatred, and delusion

concepts.name: Samsara
concepts.description: The endless cycle of birth, death, and rebirth driven by karma and desire

items.name: Bodhi Tree
items.description: Sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Buddha attained enlightenment

items.name: Lotus
items.description: Sacred flower symbolizing creation, rebirth, and the sun's daily resurrection

items.name: Sandalwood
items.description: Fragrant wood used in incense and meditation, aids concentration and purification

items.name: Tibetan Singing Bowl
items.description: Drilbu - Sacred Vessel of Vibrational Healing

items.name: ü¶∑ Tooth Relic of Buddha
items.description: Buddha's Canine Tooth - Sri Dalada Maligawa

items.name: Vajra
items.description: Indra's thunderbolt weapon, an indestructible divine weapon symbolizing both destruction and enlightenment

places.name: Angkor Wat
places.description: The world's largest religious monument, originally built as Hindu temple to Vishnu (1113-1150 CE), later transformed into Buddhist pilgrimage site

places.name: Bardo
places.description: Transitional state between death and rebirth where consciousness experiences visions

places.name: Borobudur
places.description: The world's largest Buddhist monument in Central Java‚Äîa 9th-century mandala-shaped temple complex representing the path to enlightenment through Mahayana Buddhist cosmology

places.name: Mount Kailash
places.description: Sacred mountain in Tibet revered by four religions as the cosmic axis mundi‚ÄîShiva's throne, Mount Meru incarnate, and source of four major Asian rivers

places.name: Mahabodhi Temple
places.description: The most sacred site in Buddhism where Prince Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment under the Bodhi Tree in Bodh Gaya, India (c. 528 BCE)

places.name: Mount Kailash
places.description: Sacred mountain and eternal abode of Lord Shiva and Parvati, one of the holiest sites in Asia

places.name: Mount K≈çya
places.description: Sacred mountain complex in Japan and spiritual center of Shingon Buddhism, founded by K≈´kai (K≈çb≈ç Daishi) in 819 CE, featuring 117 temples and the Okunoin cemetery where K≈´kai eternally meditates

places.name: Mount Meru
places.description: Sacred cosmic mountain at the center of the universe, axis mundi connecting heaven and earth

places.name: Potala Palace
places.description: Sacred abode of Avalokiteshvara and historic residence of Dalai Lama in Lhasa

places.name: Six Realms
places.description: Six destinations for rebirth: gods, asuras, humans, animals, hungry ghosts, hell beings

deitys.name: Avalokiteshvara
deitys.description: Bodhisattva of infinite compassion who hears the cries of all suffering beings

deitys.name: Gautama Buddha
deitys.description: The historical Buddha who attained enlightenment under the Bodhi Tree and taught the path to liberation

deitys.name: Guanyin
deitys.description: East Asian feminine manifestation of Avalokiteshvara, goddess of mercy and compassion

deitys.name: Manjushri
deitys.description: Bodhisattva of transcendent wisdom who wields the sword of discriminating awareness

deitys.name: Yamantaka
deitys.description: Wrathful manifestation of Manjushri who conquered Yama, the lord of death

heros.name: Dalai Lama
heros.description: Spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, considered tulku of Avalokiteshvara

heros.name: Nagarjuna
heros.description: Founder of Madhyamaka philosophy, retrieved Prajnaparamita sutras from the nagas

heros.name: Shantideva
heros.description: 8th century monk and author of Bodhicharyavatara (Guide to the Bodhisattva Way)

heros.name: Songtsen Gampo
heros.description: 7th century Tibetan king who introduced Buddhism to Tibet

heros.name: Tsongkhapa
heros.description: Founder of Gelug school of Tibetan Buddhism, considered emanation of Manjushri

magics.name: Pranayama (Breathwork)
magics.description: Ancient yogic science of breath control and life force regulation, forming the fourth limb of Raja Yoga; conscious manipulation of breath to influence prana flow through body, mind, and subtle energy channels for physical health, mental clarity, and spiritual awakening

magics.name: Chakra Work
magics.description: Energy center activation and balancing practice working with the seven primary chakras (energy wheels) along the spine, from root to crown, using visualization, breathwork, sound, and meditation to clear blockages and harmonize the subtle body
